awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. With more than 50 percent of known species found on just six percent of the Earth's surface, tropical rainforests are famous for their incredible biodiversity. Still, little is actually known about how these species originate. In large part, this gap in our knowledge exists because the bulk of evolution research focuses on plants and animals from temperate regions. As a result, we know little about species formation in the most species rich area on Earth. This project will investigate factors that drive tropical tree evolution and contribute to our basic understanding of how species form. The fellow will receive training in genomic data collection and analysis and will foster the next generation of scientists through mentoring. In order to increase the retention of post-graduate women in STEM fields the fellow will also organize panel discussions to provide insight on navigating a science career while balancing family and also to introduce students to non-academic careers in science.

The tropical tree, Protium subserratum, exhibits genetic, morphological, and defense chemistry differences associated with different soil habitats across the Amazon. Adaptation to different soils thus appears to be driving diversification within the group, and herbivore pressure may further strengthen selection across habitat boundaries. This project will integrate morphological, spectral, ecological, geographic and genomic data from herbarium collections to understand lineage diversification within P. subserratum. The evolutionary history of the species will be reconstructed using methods that account for historic and contemporary processes to test whether habitat specialization onto different soils evolved multiple times across the Amazon or whether habitat specialization onto each soil type arose once and was followed by subsequent dispersal. The hypotheses that habitat shifts explain the observed patterns of phenotypic differentiation and that genetic and phenotypic differentiation are correlated will be tested using comparative phylogenetic methods and estimates of genetic structure and gene flow. Finally, the hypothesis that herbivore pressure is strengthening selection across soil boundaries will be investigated by testing for signatures of selection in genes from the terpene synthase and flavonoid gene pathways. The fellow will develop expertise in phylogenomic, population genomic and comparative genomic analyses. The fellow will also organize panel presentations to increase participation of women in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Amazon rainforest arguably houses the greatest tree diversity on earth. These trees are an important source of food, wood, and medicine, and they play a critical role in global water and carbon cycling. While most Amazonian trees are rare a small number are very common and widespread. As a result, these dominant tree species are thought to play a disproportionately large role in many of the global ecosystem services provided by the Amazon. However, Amazonian trees are understudied and therefore the extent to which common and widespread tree species may actually represent multiple undescribed species is unknown.

This study utilized leaf material from natural history collections stored in herbaria across the U.S. to obtain DNA from individuals of the widespread and common Amazonian tree, Protium subserratum. Using these data, we were able to demonstrate that this species is actually made up of at least eight independently evolving lineages and that each lineage occupies a unique geographic area or ecologically distinct habitat. For instance, two lineages were discovered to have specialized onto unique and highly threatened white-sand forests. Another three lineages were found to occupy different elevations at the base of the Andes. We then compared leaf characteristics from herbarium specimens to determine if we could differentiate the trees in these lineages from one another based on their appearance. We found that high levels of leaf variation observed both within and among lineages precluded us from being able to distinguish these groups from one another. Thus, we consider these lineages to be cryptic meaning that they cannot be easily identified by the way they look.

The results from this study suggest that P. subserratum is in the process of transitioning from a single widespread generalist species to multiple, range restricted, specialist species. It also suggests that geographic isolation following dispersal into new regions and habitats is likely to be important for generating new diversity in tropical trees. Finally, our work adds to the body of literature suggesting that widespread Amazonian species should not necessarily be assumed to represent genetically or ecologically uniform entities. Instead, Amazonian tree taxa that are common and widespread may represent multiple species and tropical tree diversity may be greater than previously estimated.

Over the course of this project Dr. Misiewicz has contributed to broader impacts through the mentorship and training of six diverse undergraduate students and one master's student at San Jose State University, a minority serving institution. These students gained experience in generating genomic data, using herbarium specimens for geometric morphometric analyses, collecting data from the field and conducting greenhouse experiments. They were also trained in herbarium curation which includes mounting, labeling, and databasing plant specimens.

In addition to providing research experience, Dr. Misiewicz worked with her students to advance their careers in science. This included working with students to secure funding to attend conferences and present their work. In 2019, three of Dr. Misiewicz's students were awarded travel grants to present their research - a Botanical Society of America Diversity grant, a California State University Program for Education and Research in Biotechnology grant, and a Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) travel scholarship. In 2020 Dr. Misiewicz organized and lead a two-month long NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) grant writing workshop. Two of Dr. Misiewicz's mentees received the GRFP and have continued on to graduate programs at UC Davis and UCLA.  

Finally, while supported by this fellowship Dr. Misiewicz volunteered to assist in the preparation of a Department of Education CCAMPIS grant which provides subsidized childcare for low-income students attending San Jose State University (SJSU). The SJSU Associated Students Child Development Center was awarded the grant for almost $1 million in 2021.

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2022
Modified by: Tracy M Misiewicz

Image
  • (A) Leaf variation associated with white-sand and non-white sand habitats. (B) Soil affiliations for lineages within the species complex. (C) Range associated with each lineage. (D) Rapid transition from white-sand (foreground) to brown sand (background) in Peru. (E) Protium subserratum in Peru.
    Tracy Misiewicz

    Tracy M Misiewicz
    Overview of variation in range, morphology and habitat for lineages within the P. subserratum species complex.
